Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the father needs to provide it
Expectation2: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation2: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, bills spread out before me, my mind racing with numbers. As a father, I felt the weight of every dollar—my family depended on me to keep the lights on, to put food on the table. Lately, money had been tight, and I was constantly searching for ways to stretch each paycheck. Just as I was calculating what we could cut back on, I heard my dog barking loudly in the hallway. Through the thin apartment walls, I could hear my neighbor’s frustrated sigh. 

As a neighbor, I knew I was expected to keep the peace, to make sure my dog didn’t disturb others, especially in our shared spaces. But hiring a dog trainer or even a walker to help with his anxiety was another expense I simply couldn’t afford right now. My neighbor had already left a polite note asking if I could do something about the noise. I felt torn—my family needed every cent, but I also didn’t want to be the source of tension in our building. The pressure from both sides pressed in on me, and I sat there, unsure which responsibility I could afford to let down.
